verses.verse: Then Job <S%H347><s%> answered <S%H6030><s%> and said <S%H559><s%>,
Of a truth <S%H551><s%> I know <S%H3045><s%> that it is so <S%H582><s%>: But how can man be just <S%H6663><s%> with God <S%H410><s%>?
If he be <S%H2654><s%> pleased to contend <S%H7378><s%> with him <S%H6030><s%>, He cannot answer him one <S%H259><s%> of a thousand <S%H505><s%>.
He is wise <S%H2450><s%> in heart <S%H3824><s%>, and mighty <S%H533><s%> in strength <S%H3581><s%>: Who hath hardened <S%H7185><s%> himself against him <S%H7999><s%>, and prospered? --
Him that removeth <S%H6275><s%> the mountains <S%H2022><s%>, and they know <S%H3045><s%> it not <S%H2015><s%>, When he overturneth them in his anger <S%H639><s%>;
That shaketh <S%H7264><s%> the earth <S%H776><s%> out of its place <S%H4725><s%>, And the pillars <S%H5982><s%> thereof tremble <S%H6426><s%>;
That commandeth <S%H559><s%> the sun <S%H2775><s%>, and it riseth <S%H2224><s%> not <S%H2856><s%>, And sealeth up the stars <S%H3556><s%>;
That alone stretcheth out <S%H5186><s%> the heavens <S%H8064><s%>, And treadeth <S%H1869><s%> upon the waves <S%H1116><s%> of the sea <S%H3220><s%>;
That maketh <S%H6213><s%> the Bear <S%H5906><s%>, Orion <S%H3685><s%>, and the Pleiades <S%H3598><s%>, And the chambers <S%H2315><s%> of the south <S%H8486><s%>;
That doeth <S%H6213><s%> great things <S%H1419><s%> past <S%H369><s%> finding out <S%H2714><s%>, Yea <S%H6381><s%>, marvellous things without number <S%H4557><s%>.
Lo <S%H5674><s%>, he goeth by me <S%H7200><s%>, and I see him not <S%H2498><s%>: He passeth on also <S%H995><s%>, but I perceive him not.
Behold <S%H2862><s%>, he seizeth the prey <S%H7725><s%>, who can hinder him <S%H559><s%>? Who will say unto him <S%H6213><s%>, What doest thou?
God <S%H433><s%> will not withdraw <S%H7725><s%> his anger <S%H639><s%>; The helpers <S%H5826><s%> of Rahab <S%H7293><s%> do stoop under him <S%H7817><s%>.
How much less shall I answer <S%H6030><s%> him <S%H977><s%>, And choose out my words to reason with him <S%H1697><s%>?
Whom <S%H6663><s%>, though I were righteous, yet would I not answer <S%H6030><s%>; I would make supplication <S%H2603><s%> to my judge <S%H8199><s%>.
If I had called <S%H7121><s%>, and he had answered <S%H6030><s%> me <S%H539><s%>, Yet would I not believe that he hearkened <S%H238><s%> unto my voice <S%H6963><s%>.
For he breaketh <S%H7779><s%> me with a tempest <S%H8183><s%>, And multiplieth <S%H7235><s%> my wounds <S%H6482><s%> without cause <S%H2600><s%>.
He will not suffer <S%H5414><s%> me to take <S%H7725><s%> my breath <S%H7307><s%>, But filleth <S%H7646><s%> me with bitterness <S%H4472><s%>.
If we speak of strength <S%H3581><s%>, lo <S%H533><s%>, he is mighty! And if of justice <S%H4941><s%>, Who <S%H3259><s%>, saith he, will summon me?
Though I be righteous <S%H6663><s%>, mine own mouth <S%H6310><s%> shall condemn <S%H7561><s%> me <S%H8535><s%>: Though I be perfect, it shall prove me perverse <S%H6140><s%>.
I am perfect <S%H8535><s%>; I regard <S%H3045><s%> not myself <S%H5315><s%>; I despise <S%H3988><s%> my life <S%H5315><s%>.
It is all one <S%H259><s%>; therefore I say <S%H559><s%>, He destroyeth <S%H3615><s%> the perfect <S%H8535><s%> and the wicked <S%H7563><s%>.
If the scourge <S%H7752><s%> slay <S%H4191><s%> suddenly <S%H6597><s%>, He will mock <S%H3932><s%> at the trial <S%H4531><s%> of the innocent <S%H5355><s%>.

The earth <S%H776><s%> is given <S%H5414><s%> into the hand <S%H3027><s%> of the wicked <S%H7563><s%>; He covereth <S%H3680><s%> the faces <S%H6440><s%> of the judges <S%H8199><s%> thereof <S%H645><s%>: If it be not he, who then is it?
Now my days <S%H3117><s%> are swifter <S%H7043><s%> than a post <S%H7323><s%>: They flee away <S%H1272><s%>, they see <S%H7200><s%> no good <S%H2896><s%>,
They are passed away <S%H2498><s%> as <S%H5973><s%> the swift <S%H16><s%> ships <S%H591><s%>; As the eagle <S%H5404><s%> that swoopeth <S%H2907><s%> on the prey <S%H400><s%>.
If I say <S%H559><s%>, I will forget <S%H7911><s%> my complaint <S%H7879><s%>, I will put off <S%H5800><s%> my sad countenance <S%H6440><s%>, and be of good cheer <S%H1082><s%>;
I am afraid <S%H3025><s%> of all my sorrows <S%H6094><s%>, I know <S%H3045><s%> that thou wilt not hold me innocent <S%H5352><s%>.
I shall be condemned <S%H7561><s%>; Why then do I labor <S%H3021><s%> in vain <S%H1892><s%>?
If I wash <S%H7364><s%> myself with <S%H7950><s%> snow water <S%H4325><s%>, And make my hands <S%H3709><s%> never <S%H1252><s%> so clean <S%H2141><s%>;
Yet <S%H227><s%> wilt thou plunge <S%H2881><s%> me in the ditch <S%H7845><s%>, And mine own clothes <S%H8008><s%> shall abhor me <S%H8581><s%>.
For he is not a man <S%H376><s%>, as I am <S%H6030><s%>, that I should answer him <S%H935><s%>, That we should come together <S%H3162><s%> in judgment <S%H4941><s%>.
There is <S%H3426><s%> no umpire <S%H3198><s%> betwixt us <S%H7896><s%>, That might lay his hand <S%H3027><s%> upon us both <S%H8147><s%>.
Let him take <S%H5493><s%> his rod <S%H7626><s%> away <S%H5493><s%> from me <S%H367><s%>, And let not his terror make me afraid <S%H367><s%>:
Then would I speak <S%H1696><s%>, and not fear him <S%H3372><s%>; For I am not so in myself.
